description.en:
Letchworth, the world's first garden city, is located about 30 miles north of London. Its design was intended to bring together the best of town and country, as defined in Ebenezer Howard's visionary 1898 book, Garden Cities of To-morrow. Today, geographically, demographically and physically, Letchworth leans in part towards London and the metropolis. This explorative work considers the contributions of the key players turning ideals into reality - It begins with E. Howard and his philosophical vision of garden cities; exploring what his key contributions have been, in terms of food - It also examines the contribution of early garden city planners, Barry Parker and Robert Unwin.
Robert Unwin, and more specifically what place food had in the original 1903 and later master plan. of 1903 and later - We then focus on what of these original principles remains today in Letchworth of Garden Cities Food - November 201810www.ruaf.org these original principles and this is done through a detailed multi-scale examination of the various food-related spaces and their use. It concludes on the legacy of the City region as a concept - We then examine how Letchworth positively contributed to food production in times of both World Wars and discuss why such resilience and uniqueness was possible and propose three explanatory factors that led to creative and multiple food-related associations over time. and multiple food-related associations over time. This section highlights the contributions of residents and their organization, and primarily the Horticultural and Allotment Society, and attempts to identify the extent to which they shaped particular food spaces - Finally, we draw lessons from Letchworth, as the first Garden City, that could be useful for food planning in 21st century city-regions in other parts of the world.

Sa conception visait à réunir le meilleur de la ville et de la campagne, tel que défini dans le livre visionnaire d'Ebenezer Howard de 1898, Garden Cities of To-morrow (Cités-jardins de demain).
